title: 109_s1165
content: The Act may be cited as the "James Campbell National Wildlife Refuge Expansion Act of 2005". The United States Fish and Wildlife Service manages the James Campbell National Wildlife Refuge to promote the recovery of 4 endangered Hawaiian waterbirds on 240 acres of wetland habitat. The United States Fish and Wildlife Service manages the James Campbell National Wildlife Refuge to protect endangered species habitat and improve management, including acquiring additional land for inclusion in the Refuge. The United States Fish and Wildlife Service has identified approximately 800 acres of high-value wildlife habitat owned by the estate of James Campbell for inclusion in the Refuge. The land features coastal dunes, wetlands, and coastal strand that promote biological diversity for threatened and endangered species. The estate of James Campbell owns high-value wildlife habitat on the Kahuku Coast, featuring coastal dunes, wetlands, and coastal strand that support diverse species including endangered Hawaiian waterbirds, migratory shorebirds, waterfowl, seabirds, native plant species, monk seals, and green sea turtles. The Refuge supports endangered Hawaiian waterbirds, migratory shorebirds, waterfowl, seabirds, native plant species, monk seals, and green sea turtles. Expanding the Refuge will provide more opportunities for wildlife observation, photography, and environmental education. Expanding the Refuge to include habitats for green sea turtles due to coastal development. This will increase opportunities for wildlife observation, photography, and environmental education. Acquisition of land will create a large, ecologically-intact unit with buffer land to reduce impacts and flood damage. Acquiring land to expand the Refuge will create a large, ecologically-intact unit with buffer land to reduce impacts and flood damage in Kahuku town. The Act defines key terms such as Director, Refuge, and Secretary. The Refuge refers to the James Campbell National Wildlife Refuge established under the Endangered Species Act of 1973. The James Campbell National Wildlife Refuge is expanded by approximately 1,100 acres as depicted on a map dated October 20, 2005. The Secretary has the authority to make minor boundary modifications to achieve conservation goals or facilitate property acquisition within the Refuge. The Secretary has the authority to make modifications to the boundary of the James Campbell National Wildlife Refuge to achieve conservation goals or facilitate property acquisition. The map depicting the expansion remains available for inspection at the US Fish and Wildlife Service office, with notice published in the Federal Register and local publications. The map showing the expansion of the James Campbell National Wildlife Refuge is available for inspection at a designated office of the US Fish and Wildlife Service. The Secretary will publish a notice in the Federal Register and local publications regarding the availability of the map. SEC. 5. ACQUISITION OF LAND AND WATER: The Secretary may acquire land described in section 4(a) to become part of the Refuge and be administered according to the law. SEC. 6. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS: Sums necessary to carry out this Act are authorized to be appropriated.
